text: Welcome to Exploring Computing.

Today's video is human
computer interaction.

Human Computer
Interaction, or HCI

is an important field of
study in computer science.

It focuses on how to
improve interactions
between humans and computers.

And the computers that
you are working on today

are a good sign of
the success of HCI,

because HCI is responsible for
things like the Windows, icon,

mouse, and point, or WIMP

And the fact that you are all

instead of command
line interfaces

where we're typing
at the computer

shows that HCI researchers have

Hot topics currently
in HCI include

virtual and augmented
reality, speech commands,

using your hands
to interact with the computer.

And HCI researchers are
even studying brain computer
interfaces.

that user interface

trying to design a new UI.

The first thing you should
do some need finding.

We want to determine what
the user's actual needs are.

And so we're going to spend some
time observing the workplace,

studying the current

potential users.

We then going to determine
what the different roles
within that workplace are.

And what the different

And then we're going
to do some prototyping.

We're going to do some

and then we're going to iterate.

This last part is
really important

because it turns out that we are
particularly good at coming up

with programs that actually
help in the workplace.

And so it's very important
that not only do we

interview people, and
come up with ideas based

on what the feedback
that they're giving us

in the interviews are, but that
we test them out and try them.

Again, it's actually
not uncommon for users

to think that they
want a program.

And then when they actually
try out the program to realize,

oh, this isn't as
helpful as I thought.

I think maybe what we really
want is this other thing.

And so that process
of iteration where

you work in conjunction
with your potential users

to try out different things,
and ultimately really identify

what they actually
need as opposed

to what their initial
perceived concerns are
is super important.

The prototypes you can
build range in quality

from low-fidelity
to high-fidelity

are sometimes referred
to as lo-fi to hi-fi.

And so examples include very
low fidelity paper sketches

where you just draw diagrams
on a piece of paper.

Now, these can still be used
for user interface experiments.

So you can talk to people
about the process by which they

go from one diagram

and fonts.

But that wire frame

a good idea of what
sort of information

And we can have a mock-up--

a higher quality
mock-up with the fonts

And then we can have higher
fidelity prototypes where

the user can actually
interact with them

and press certain
buttons and so.

they would hit

it only goes to results

prototypes

can give better
